default: (a) {@item Greataxe|phb} or (b) {@item Battleaxe|phb}, {@item shield|phb}, and 10 GP

entries: Barbarians are warriors defined by their connection to the primal forces of the multiverse, which manifests as a Rage. Far more than a mere emotion, and not limited to anger or fury, a Barbarian's Rage is an incarnation of a predator's ferocity, a storm's unrelenting assault, and the churning turmoil of the sea.

Some Barbarians personify their Rage as a fierce spirit or revered forebear. Others see it as a connection to the pain and anguish of the world, as an impersonal tangle of wild magic, or as an expression of their own deepest self. For every Barbarian, their Rage is a power that fuels not just battle prowess but also uncanny reflexes and heightened senses.

Some Barbarians are uncomfortable when hedged in by walls and crowds, preferring to live in regions of unspoiled natural vitality. Others cherish the primal forces at work in farmlands and recognize the vitality of cities. Barbarians of all sorts embrace their place in the multiverse, valuing keen instincts and raw physicality.

Even without the power of their Rage, Barbarians are skilled in combat and the use of weapons. When they do call on their Rage, it gives them superhuman strength and resilience. It also heightens their senses and reflexes, making the Rage useful beyond combat.

Barbarians often serve as protectors and leaders in their communities. They charge headlong into danger so those who are under their protection don't have to. Their courage in the face of danger makes Barbarians perfectly suited for adventuring.

classFeature.name: Rage
entries: You can imbue yourself with a primal power that is called your Rage, a force that grants you extraordinary might and resilience. You can enter it as a Bonus Action, provided you aren't wearing Heavy Armor.
While active, your Rage has the following effects:

items.name: Damage Resistance
entries: You have Resistance to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing damage.

items.name: Rage Damage
entries: When you make an attack with a weapon using Strength or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} and deal damage to the target, you gain a bonus to the damage that increases as you gain levels as a Barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.

items.name: Strength Advantage
entries: You have Advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.

items.name: No Concentration or Spells
entries: You can't maintain Concentration, and you can't cast spells.

The Rage lasts until the end of your next turn, and it ends early if you don Heavy Armor or have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition. If your Rage is still active on your next turn, you can extend the Rage for another round by doing one or more of the following:

items: Make an attack roll against an enemy.
Force an enemy to make a saving throw.
Take a Bonus Action to extend your Rage.

entries: Each time the Rage is extended, it lasts until the end of your next turn. You can maintain a Rage for up to 10 minutes.

You can enter your Rage the number of times shown for your Barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian table. You regain one expended use when you finish a Short Rest, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: While you aren't wearing any armor, your base Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity and Constitution modifiers. You can use a Shield and still gain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Your training with weapons allows you to use the Mastery property of two kinds of Simple or Martial Melee weapons of your choice, such as Greataxes and Handaxes. Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, you can practice weapon drills and change one of those weapon choices.
When you reach certain levels in this class, you gain the ability to use the Mastery properties of more kinds of weapons, as shown in the Weapon Mastery column of the Barbarian table.

classFeature.name: Danger Sense
entries: You gain an uncanny sense of when things aren't as they should be, giving you an edge when you dodge perils. You have Advantage on Dexterity saving throws, unless you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition.

classFeature.name: Reckless Attack
entries: You can throw aside all concern for defense to attack with fierce desperation. When you make your first attack roll on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you Advantage on attack rolls using Strength until the start of your next turn, but attack rolls against you have Advantage during that time.

classFeature.name: Barbarian Subclass
entries: You gain a Barbarian subclass of your choice: Path of the Berserker, Path of the Wild Heart, Path of the World Tree, or Path of the Zealot. The Path of the World Tree is detailed after this class's description.

A subclass is a specialization that grants you special features at certain Barbarian levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Barbarian level and lower.

classFeature.name: Primal Knowledge
entries: You gain proficiency in another skill of your choice from the list of skills available to Barbarians at level 1.

In addition, while your Rage is active, you can channel primal power when you attempt certain tasks; whenever you make an ability check using one of the following skills, you can make it as a Strength check even if it normally uses a different ability: {@skill Acrobatics}, {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Perception}, {@skill Stealth}, or {@skill Survival}. When you use this ability, your Strength represents primal power coursing through you, honing your agility and senses.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.
As shown on the Barbarian table, you gain this feature again at levels 8, 12, 16, and 19.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Fast Movement
entries: Your speed increases by 10 feet while you aren't wearing Heavy Armor.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Barbarian subclass.

classFeature.name: Feral Instinct
entries: Your instincts are so honed that you have Advantage on Initiative rolls.

classFeature.name: Instinctive Pounce
entries: As part of the Bonus Action you take to enter your Rage, you can {@variantrule Move|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} up to half your Speed.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Brutal Strike
entries: If you use Reckless Attack, you can forgo Advantage on the next attack roll you make on your turn with a Strength-based attack. If that attack hits, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d10} damage of the same type dealt by the weapon or {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, and you can cause one Brutal Strike effect of your choice. You have the following effect options.

entries.name: Forceful Blow
entries: The target is pushed 15 feet straight away from you. You can then Move up to half your Speed straight toward the target without provoking Opportunity Attacks.

entries.name: Hamstring Blow
entries: The target's Speed is reduced by 15 feet until the start of your next turn.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Barbarian subclass.

classFeature.name: Relentless Rage
entries: Your Rage can keep you fighting despite grievous wounds. If you drop to 0 Hit Points while your Rage is active and don't die outright, you can make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw. If you succeed, your Hit Points instead change to a number equal to twice your Barbarian level.

Each time you use this feature after the first, the DC increases by 5. When you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, the DC resets to 10.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Brutal Strike Improvement
entries: You have honed new ways to attack furiously. The following effects are now among your Brutal Strike options.

entries.name: Staggering Blow
entries: The target has Disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes, and it can't make Opportunity Attacks until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Sundering Blow
entries: Your blow leaves an opening in the creature's defense for an ally until the start of your next turn. The next attack roll made by another creature against the target gains a bonus to that roll equal to your Rage Damage.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Barbarian subclass.

classFeature.name: Persistent Rage
entries: When you roll Initiative, you can regain all expended uses of Rage. After you regain uses of Rage in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}.

In addition, your Rage is so fierce that it now lasts for 10 minutes without you needing to do anything to extend it from round to round. The Rage ends early if you have the {@condition Unconscious|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, not the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, condition or don Heavy Armor.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Brutal Strike Improvement
entries: The extra damage your Brutal Strike deals increases to {@damage 2d10}. In addition, you can use two different Brutal Strike effects when you use your Brutal Strike feature.

classFeature.name: Indomitable Might
entries: If your total for a Strength check or Strength saving throw is less than your Strength score, you can use that score in place of the total.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Primal Champion
entries: You embody primal power. Your Strength and Constitution scores increase by 4, and their maximum is now 26.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the World Tree
entries: Barbarians who follow the Path of the World Tree believe that their Rage links them to the cosmic ash tree Yggdrasil. This "world tree" grows among the Outer Planes, connecting them to each other and to the many worlds of the Material Plane, and the greatest plants on every world are said to be distant descendants of mighty Yggdrasil. These Barbarians draw on their connection to the world tree as a source of vitality and as a means of travel across the multiverse.

subclassFeature.name: Vitality of the Tree
entries: Your Rage taps into the lifeforce of the World Tree. You gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Vitality Surge
entries: When you activate your Rage, you gain a number of Temporary Hit Points equal to your Barbarian level.

entries.name: Life-Giving Force
entries: At the start of each of your turns while your Rage is active, you can choose another creature within 10 feet of yourself to gain Temporary Hit Points. To determine the number of Temporary Hit Points, roll a number of d6s equal to your Rage Damage bonus, and add them together. If any of these Temporary Hit Points remain when your Rage ends, they vanish.

subclassFeature.name: Branches of the Tree
entries: While your Rage is active, whenever a creature you can see starts its turn within 30 feet of you, you can use your Reaction to summon spectral branches of the World Tree around it. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC equal to 8 plus your Proficiency Bonus plus your Strength modifier) or be teleported to an unoccupied space you can see within 5 feet of yourself or in the nearest unoccupied space you can see. The space the target teleports to must be on a surface or liquid that can support it; otherwise, the target doesn't teleport.
After the target teleports, you can reduce its Speed to 0 until the end of the current turn.

entries.name: Design Note: Voluntarily Failing a Save
entries: The 2024 {@i Player's Handbook} will clarify that any creature can voluntarily fail any saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Battering Roots
entries: Tendrils of the World Tree extend from your Melee weapons. During your turn, while you wield a Melee weapon with the Heavy or Versatile property, your reach with that weapon increases by 10 feet. When you hit with this weapon, you can activate the Push or Topple property in addition to any other Mastery property you are using with that weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Travel Along the Tree
entries: You can briefly travel along the World Tree. When you activate your Rage and as a Bonus Action while it's active, you can teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space you can see.

In addition, when you teleport using this feature, you can bring up to six willing creatures who are within 10 feet of yourself, and the range you can teleport increases to 500 feet. Each creature teleports to an unoccupied space of your choice within 10 feet of your destination space. You can teleport other creatures with you only once per Rage.

feat.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: Increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feat. However, if you're at least level 19, that maximum increases to 22.

spell.name: Conjure Animals
entries: You summon nature spirits that take the form of a Large swarm of spectral animals in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. The swarm lasts for the duration, and you choose the animal form of the spirits, such as wolves, serpents, or birds.

When a creature hostile to you enters a space within 10 feet of the swarm for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, you can make a melee spell attack against that creature. On a hit, the target takes Radiant damage equal to {@damage 2d10} plus your spellcasting ability modifier.

You have Advantage on Strength saving throws while you're within 10 feet of the swarm, and when you {@variantrule Move|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} on your turn, you can also move the swarm up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 4 or higher, the damage increases by {@damage 1d10} for each slot level above 3.

spell.name: Conjure Celestial
entries: You summon the protective presence of a Celestial spirit, which manifests as a pillar of divine light that shines in a 10-foot-radius, 40-foot-high Cylinder centered on a point within range. Until the spell ends, Bright Light fills the Cylinder, and when you {@variantrule Move|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} on your turn, you can also move the Cylinder up to 30 feet.
When a creature enters the Cylinder for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, you can bathe that creature in one of the following lights:

entries.name: Healing Light
entries: The creature that isn't an Undead or a Construct regains Hit Points equal to {@dice 4d12} plus your spellcasting modifier. A creature can be healed by this light only once per casting of this spell.

entries.name: Searing Radiance
entries: The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 8d12} Radiant damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 8 or higher, the healing and damage increase by {@damage 1d12} for each slot level above 7.

spell.name: Conjure Elemental
entries: You summon an Elemental spirit that fills a 10-foot Cube within range. The spirit lasts for the duration and is composed of air, earth, fire, or water (your choice) when you cast this spell.

When a creature hostile to you {@variantrule Move|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|Moves} within 5 feet of the spirit, you can make a melee spell attack against that creature. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 8d8} damage of a type determined by the spirit's element: Bludgeoning (earth), Cold (water), Fire (fire), or Lightning (air). If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is also pulled into the Cube and has the Restrained condition. At the start of each of its turns, the target must make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a success, the target frees itself. On a failure, the target takes {@damage 4d8} damage of the same type as the spell attack. The spirit can have only one creature restrained at a time.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 6 or higher, the damage increases by {@damage 2d8} for each slot level above 5.

spell.name: Conjure Fey
entries: You summon the awesome presence of a Medium Fey spirit in an unoccupied space you can see within range. The spirit lasts for the duration, and it looks like a Fey creature of your choice. When the spirit appears, you can immediately make one melee spell attack against a creature within 5 feet of the spirit. On a hit, the target takes Psychic damage equal to {@damage 3d12} plus your spellcasting ability modifier, and the target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or have the Frightened condition until the start of your next turn.
As a Bonus Action on your later turns, you can teleport the spirit to an unoccupied space you can see within 30 feet of the space it left and repeat the attack against a creature within 5 feet of it.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 7 or higher, the damage increases by {@damage 2d12} for each slot level above 6.

spell.name: Conjure Minor Elementals
entries: You summon elemental spirits that a flit around you for the duration. Until the spell ends, any attack you make deals an extra {@damage 2d8} damage when you hit a creature within 15 feet of you. This damage is Bludgeoning, Cold, Fire, or Lightning (your choice when you make the attack).
In addition, the ground within 15 feet of you is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} for your enemies.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 5 or higher, the damage increases by {@damage 2d8} and the range of {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} increases by 5 feet for each slot level above 4.

spell.name: Conjure Woodland Beings
entries: You summon nature spirits that flit about you for the duration. Until the spell ends, each creature you choose that enters a space within 10 feet of you for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a Wisdom saving throw, taking {@damage 5d8} Force damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.
In addition, you can take the {@action Disengage} action as a Bonus Action for the spell's duration.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 6 or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 5.

spell.name: Cure Wounds
entries: A creature you touch regains a number of Hit Points equal to {@dice 2d8} plus your spellcasting ability modifier. This spell has no effect on Constructs and Undead.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 2 or higher, the healing increases by {@dice 2d8} for each slot level above 1.

spell.name: Fount of Moonlight
entries: A cool light wreathes your body for the duration, emitting Bright Light in a 20-foot radius and Dim Light for an additional 20 feet.
Until the spell ends, you have Resistance to Radiant damage, and your melee attacks deal an extra {@damage 2d6} Radiant damage on a hit.

In addition, immediately after you take damage from a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself, you can use your Reaction to force the creature to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature has the Blinded condition until the end of your next turn.

spell.name: Healing Word
entries: A creature of your choice that you can see within range regains Hit Points equal to {@dice 2d4} plus your spellcasting ability modifier. This spell has no effect on Constructs or Undead.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 2 or higher, the healing increases by {@dice 2d4} for each slot level above 1.

spell.name: Mass Cure Wounds
entries: A wave of healing energy emanates from a point you can see within range. Choose up to six creatures in a 30-foot-radius Sphere centered on that point. Each target regains Hit Points equal to {@dice 5d8} plus your spellcasting ability modifier. This spell has no effect on Constructs or Undead.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 6 or higher, the healing increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 5.

spell.name: Mass Healing Word
entries: As you call out words of restoration, up to six creatures of your choice that you can see within range regain Hit Points equal to {@dice 2d4} plus your spellcasting ability modifier. This spell has no effect on Constructs or Undead.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 4 or higher, the healing increases by {@dice 1d4} for each slot level above 3.

spell.name: Power Word Fortify
entries: You speak a word of power that fortifies up to six creatures you can see within range. The spell bestows 120 Temporary Hit Points, which are divided equally among the spell's recipients.

spell.name: Starry Wisp
entries: You launch a mote of light at one creature or object within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d8} Radiant damage, and until the end of your next turn, it emits Dim Light in a 10-foot radius and can't benefit from the Invisible condition.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Cantrip Upgrade
entries: This spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d8} when you reach levels 5 ({@dice 2d8}), 11 ({@dice 3d8}), and 17 ({@dice 4d8}).

baseitem.name: Lance
entries: {@note The lance does not have the Two-Handed property when mounted.}

item.name: Net
entries: When you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} action on your turn, you can replace one of your attacks with a throw of the net at a creature within 15 feet of yourself. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw against a DC equal to 8 + your Proficiency Bonus + your Dexterity modifier. The target succeeds automatically if it's Huge or larger.

On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Restrained} condition until it escapes the net. To escape, the target must use its action to make a {@dc 10} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check, escaping on a success. A creature within 5 feet of the target can use its action to attempt the same thing. Destroying the net (AC 10; 5 HP; immunity to Bludgeoning, Poison, and Psychic damage) also frees the target, ending the effect.

item.name: Priest's Pack
entries: A Priest's Pack contains the following items:

entries.name: Heavy
entries: A Heavy weapon is unwieldy compared to other weapons. You have Disadvantage on your attack rolls with a Heavy weapon if it's a melee weapon and your Strength score isn't at least 13 and if it's a ranged weapon and your Dexterity score isn't at least 13.

entries.name: Light
entries: When you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} action on your turn and attack with a Light weapon, you can make one extra attack as a Bonus Action later on the same turn. That extra attack must be made with a different Light weapon, and you don't add your ability modifier to the extra attack's damage, unless that modifier is negative.

For example, if you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} action on your turn and have a Shortsword in one hand and a Dagger in the other—each of which has the Light property—you can make one attack with each weapon, using your action and a Bonus Action, but you don't add your Strength or Dexterity modifier to the damage roll of the Bonus Action, unless that modifier is negative.

entries.name: Thrown
entries: If a weapon has the Thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack, and you can draw that weapon as part of the attack.

If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a Handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a Dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the Dagger has the Finesse property.

itemMastery.name: Cleave
entries: If you hit a creature with a melee attack using this weapon, you can make an attack roll with the weapon against a second creature within 5 feet of the first that is also within your reach. On a hit, the second creature takes the weapon's damage, but don't add your ability modifier to that damage, unless that modifier is negative. You can make this extra attack only once per turn.

itemMastery.name: Graze
entries: If your attack roll with this weapon misses a creature, you can deal damage to that creature equal to the ability modifier you used to make the attack roll. This damage is the same type dealt by the weapon, and the damage can't be increased in any way, other than increasing the ability modifier.

itemMastery.name: Nick
entries: When you make the extra attack of the Light property, you can make it as part of the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} action, instead of as a Bonus Action. You can still make this extra attack only once per turn.

itemMastery.name: Push
entries: If you hit a creature with this weapon, you can push the creature up to 10 feet straight away from yourself if it is Large or smaller.

itemMastery.name: Sap
entries: If you hit a creature with this weapon, that creature has Disadvantage on its next attack roll before the start of your next turn.

itemMastery.name: Slow
entries: If you hit a creature with this weapon and deal damage to the creature, you can reduce its Speed by 10 feet until the start of your next turn. If you hit the creature more than once with this property, the Speed reduction doesn't exceed 10 feet.

itemMastery.name: Topple
entries: If you hit a creature with this weapon, you can force the creature to make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to 8 + your Proficiency Bonus + the ability modifier used to make the attack roll. On a failed save, the creature has the {@condition Prone} condition.

itemMastery.name: Vex
entries: If you hit a creature with this weapon and deal damage to the creature, you have Advantage on your next attack roll against that creature before the end of your next turn.

variantrule.name: Armor Training
entries: Armor training is the new name for armor proficiency. Any existing rule that involves armor proficiency now applies to armor training.

If you wear Light, Medium, or Heavy Armor and lack armor training with that type of armor, you have Disadvantage on any {@variantrule D20 Tests|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|d20 Test} you make that involves Strength or Dexterity, and you can't cast spells.
If you equip a Shield and lack armor training with it, you don't gain the Armor Class bonus of the Shield.

variantrule.name: Climb Speed
entries: A Climb Speed can be used to traverse a vertical surface without expending the extra movement normally associated with climbing.
Some creatures have the Spider Climb trait, which allows their Climb Speed to work even on the underside of horizontal surfaces.

variantrule.name: Creature Type
entries: Every creature in D&D, including every player character, has a special tag in the rules that identifies the type of creature it is. Most player characters are of the Humanoid type.
Here's a list of the game's creature types in alphabetical order:

These types don't have rules themselves, but some rules in the game affect creatures of certain types in different ways. For example, the description of the {@spell Charm Person} spell specifies that its target must be a Humanoid.

variantrule.name: D20 Tests
entries: The term d20 Test encompasses the three main {@dice d20} rolls of the game: ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws. If something in the game affects d20 Tests, it affects all three of these rolls.
The DM determines whether a d20 Test is warranted in any given circumstance.

variantrule.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: If a space is Difficult Terrain, every foot of movement in that space costs 1 extra foot. For example, moving 5 feet through Difficult Terrain costs 10 feet of movement. Difficult Terrain isn't cumulative; either a space is Difficult Terrain or it isn't.
A space is Difficult Terrain for a creature if the space contains any of the following:

items: Creature that isn't Tiny or your ally
Furniture that is one size smaller than you or larger
Liquid that's between shin- and waist-deep (any deeper and you need to swim)
Narrow opening that is sized for a creature one size smaller
Pit or another gap of 2–5 feet

entries: The DM may determine that other things make a space count as Difficult Terrain, based on the examples here.

variantrule.name: Expertise
entries: {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} is a special feature that enhances your use of a particular skill proficiency. If you gain Expertise, you gain it in one skill in which you have proficiency. You can never have {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} in the same skill proficiency more than once.
When you make an ability check with a skill proficiency in which you have Expertise, your Proficiency Bonus is doubled for that check.

variantrule.name: Fly Speed
entries: A {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} can be used to travel through the air. While you have a Fly Speed, you can stay aloft until you land, fall, or die.

While flying, you fall if you lack the Hover trait and have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} or {@condition Prone} condition or your {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} is reduced to 0.

variantrule.name: Heroic Advantage
entries: When you have Heroic Advantage (also called Inspiration), you can expend it to give yourself Advantage on a {@variantrule D20 Tests|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|d20 Test}. You decide to do so immediately after rolling the {@dice d20}.

entries.name: Gaining Heroic Advantage
entries: The DM can award Heroic Advantage to a player character who's done something that is particularly heroic or in character.
Some game features, such as the Human, also award Heroic Advantage.

entries.name: Only One at a Time
entries: You can never have more than one instance of Heroic Advantage. If something gives it to you and you already have it, you can give it to a player character in your group who lacks it.

variantrule.name: Knocking Out a Creature
entries: Sometimes an attacker wants to knock out a foe rather than deal a killing blow. When an attacker would reduce a creature to 0 Hit Points with a Melee Attack, the attacker can instead reduce the creature to 1 Hit Point. The creature then has the {@condition Unconscious|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition and starts a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}.

The creature remains {@condition Unconscious|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} until it regains any Hit Points or until someone uses an action to administer first aid to it, which requires a successful {@dc 10} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check.

variantrule.name: Long Rest
entries: A {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} is a period of extended downtime—at least 8 hours long—available to any creature. During a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, you sleep for at least 6 hours and perform no more than 2 hours of light activity, such as reading, talking, eating, or standing watch.
During the sleep, you have the {@condition Unconscious|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition.

entries.name: Benefits of the Rest
entries: To start a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, you must have at least 1 Hit Point. When you finish the rest, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Regain All HP
entries: You regain all lost Hit Points.

items.name: Regain All HD
entries: You regain all spent Hit Dice.

items.name: HP Max Restored
entries: If your Hit Point Maximum was reduced, it returns to normal.

items.name: Ability Scores Restored
entries: If any of your Ability Scores were reduced, they return to normal.

items.name: Exhaustion Reduced
entries: If you have the {@condition Exhaustion} condition, your level of exhaustion decreases by 1.

items.name: Special Feature
entries: Some features are recharged by a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}. If you have such a feature, it recharges in the way specified in its description.
After you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, you must wait at least 16 hours before starting another one.

entries.name: Interrupting the Rest
entries: A {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} is stopped by the following interruptions:

items: Casting a spell other than a cantrip
1 hour of walking or other physical exertion

entries: If the rest was at least 1 hour long before the interruption, you gain the benefits of a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}.
You can resume a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} immediately after an interruption. If you do so, the rest requires 1 additional hour to finish per interruption.

variantrule.name: Move
entries: When you Move, you can go a distance equal to your Speed or less. For example, if you have a Speed of 30 feet, you can go up to 30 feet when you Move. {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} can slow you down.

entries.name: Breaking Up Your Move
entries: You can break up your Move, using some of its movement before and after any action you take on the same turn. For example, if you have a Speed of 30 feet, you could go 10 feet, take an action, and then go 20 feet.

entries.name: Moving Around Other Creatures
entries: During your Move, you can pass through the space of an ally, a creature that has the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition, a Tiny creature, or a creature who is two sizes larger or smaller than you.
Another creature's space is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} for you, unless that creature is Tiny or your ally.
You can't willingly end your Move in a space occupied by another creature.

entries.name: Changes to Your Speeds
entries: If an effect increases or decreases your Speed for a time, any special speed you have increases or decreases by an equal amount for the same duration. For example, if your Speed is reduced to 0 and you have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, your {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} is also reduced to 0. Similarly, if your Speed is halved and you have a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, your {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} is also halved.

variantrule.name: Ritual Casting
entries: If you have a spell prepared that has the Ritual tag, you can cast that spell as a Ritual. A special feature is no longer required for Ritual casting. All the other rules on Rituals in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} still apply.

variantrule.name: Short Rest
entries: To start a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, you must have at least 1 Hit Point. When you finish the rest, you gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Benefits of the Rest
entries: To start a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, you must have at least 1 Hit Point. When you finish the rest, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Spend Hit Dice
entries: You can spend one or more of your Hit Dice to regain Hit Points. For each Hit Die you spend in this way, roll the die, and add your Constitution modifier to it. You regain Hit Points equal to the total (minimum of 1 Hit Point). You can decide to spend an additional Hit Die after each roll.

items.name: Special Feature
entries: Some features are recharged by a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}. If you have such a feature, it recharges in the way specified in its description.

entries.name: Interrupting the Rest
entries: A {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} is stopped by the following interruptions:

items: Casting a spell other than a cantrip

entries: An interrupted {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} confers no benefits, and it must be started over to confer any.

variantrule.name: Swim Speed
entries: A Swim Speed can be used to travel through a liquid without expending the extra movement normally associated with swimming.

variantrule.name: Telepathy
entries: Telepathy is a magical ability that allows a creature to communicate mentally with another creature within a specified range. The contacted creature doesn't need to share a language with the telepath to understand this communication, but the contacted creature must be able to understand at least one language or be telepathic itself to understand.

A telepath doesn't need to see a contacted creature, and the telepath can start or end the telepathic contact at any time (no action required). Telepathic contact is broken as soon as the contacted creature is no longer within the telepathy's range, if the telepath contacts a different creature within range, or if the telepath has the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition.

A creature without telepathy can receive telepathic messages but can't initiate a telepathic conversation. Once a telepathic conversation starts, the nontelepath can communicate mentally to the telepath until the telepathic connection ends.

variantrule.name: Teleportation
entries: Teleportation is a special kind of magical transportation. If you teleport, you disappear and reappear elsewhere instantly, without moving through the intervening space. This transportation doesn't expend movement, unless a rule tells you otherwise, and teleportation never provokes Opportunity Attacks.

When you teleport, all the equipment you're wearing and carrying teleports with you. If you're touching another creature when you teleport, that creature doesn't teleport with you unless the teleportation effect says otherwise.
If the destination space of your teleportation is occupied by another creature or blocked by a solid obstacle, you instead appear in the nearest unoccupied space of your choice.
The description of a teleportation effect tells you if you must see the teleportation's destination.

variantrule.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: If you have proficiency with a tool, you can add your Proficiency Bonus to any ability check you make that uses that tool.

If you have proficiency in the skill that's also used with that check, you have Advantage on the check too. This means you can benefit from both a skill and a tool proficiency on the same ability check.

variantrule.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: An {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} is a Melee attack that involves you using your body to damage, grapple, or shove a target within 5 feet of you.
Whenever you use your Unarmed Strike, choose one of the following options for its effect:

items.name: Damage
entries: You make an attack roll against the target. Your bonus to hit equals your Strength modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. On a hit, the target takes Bludgeoning damage equal to 1 + your Strength modifier.

items.name: Grapple
entries: The target must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (it chooses which), or it has the {@condition Grappled|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition. The DC for the saving throw and any escape attempts equals 8 + your Strength modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. This grapple is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you and if you have a hand free to grab it.

items.name: Shove
entries: The target must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (it chooses which), or you either push the target 5 feet away or cause it to have the {@condition Prone} condition. The DC for the saving throw equals 8 + your Strength modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. This shove is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you.

condition.name: Dazed
entries: While Dazed, you experience the following effect:

items.name: Limited Activity
entries: You can {@variantrule Move|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} or take one action on your turn, not both. You also can't take a Bonus Action or a Reaction.

condition.name: Grappled
entries: While Grappled, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Speed 0
entries: Your Speed is 0 and can't change.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: You have Disadvantage on attack rolls against any target other than the grappler.

items.name: Movable
entries: The grappler can drag or carry you when it {@variantrule Move|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|Moves}, but every foot of movement costs it 1 extra foot, unless you are Tiny or two or more sizes smaller than the grappler.

items.name: Escape
entries: While Grappled, you can use your action to make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check against the grapple's escape DC, ending the condition on yourself on a success. The condition also ends if the grappler has the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition or if the distance between you and the grappler exceeds the grapple's range.

condition.name: Incapacitated
entries: While Incapacitated, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Inactive
entries: You can't take any action, Bonus Action, or Reaction.

items.name: No Concentration
entries: Your {@status Concentration} is broken.

items.name: Speechless
entries: You can't speak.

items.name: Surprised
entries: If you're {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}when you roll Initiative, you have Disadvantage on the roll.

condition.name: Invisible
entries: While Invisible, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Concealed
entries: You aren't affected by any effect that requires its target to be seen.

items.name: Surprise
entries: If you're Invisible when you roll Initiative, you have Advantage on the roll.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: Attack rolls against you have Disadvantage, and your attack rolls have Advantage. If a creature can somehow see you, as with magic or {@sense Blindsight|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, you don't gain this benefit against that creature.

condition.name: Unconscious
entries: While Unconscious, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Inert
entries: You have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} and {@condition Prone} conditions, and you drop whatever you're holding. When this condition ends, you remain {@condition Prone}.

items.name: Speed 0
entries: Your Speed is 0 and can't change.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: Attack rolls against you have Advantage.

items.name: Fail Str. and Dex. Saves.
entries: You automatically fail Strength and Dexterity saving throws.

items.name: Critical Hits
entries: Any attack roll that hits you is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of you.

items.name: Unaware
entries: You're unaware of your surroundings.

action.name: Attack
entries: When you take the Attack action, you can make one attack with a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}.

entries.name: Equipping and Unequipping Weapons
entries: You can either equip or unequip one weapon when you make an attack as part of this action. You do so either before or after the attack. If you equip a weapon before an attack, you don't need to use it for that attack.
Equipping a weapon includes drawing it from a sheath, picking it up, or retrieving it from a container. Unequipping a weapon includes sheathing, stowing, or dropping it.

entries.name: Moving Between Attacks
entries: If you {@variantrule Move|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} on your turn, you can use some or all of that movement to move between the attacks of this action if you have a feature, such as Extra Attack, that gives you more than one attack as part of the Attack action.

action.name: Help
entries: When you take the Help action, you do one of the following:

items.name: Assist Ability Check
entries: Choose one of your skill or {@variantrule tool proficiency|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|tool proficiencies} and one ally who can perceive you. You give Advantage to the next ability check that ally makes with the chosen skill or tool. This benefit expires if the ally doesn't use it before the start of your next turn. To give this assistance, you must be near enough to the ally to assist verbally or physically when the ally makes the check. The DM has final say on whether your assistance is possible.

items.name: Assist Attack Roll
entries: You momentarily distract an enemy within 5 feet of you, giving Advantage to the next attack roll by one of your allies against that enemy. This benefit expires at the start of your next turn.

action.name: Hide
entries: With the Hide action, you try to conceal yourself. To do so stealthily, you must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check while you're Heavily Obscured or behind Three-Quarters Cover or Total Cover, and you must be out of any visible enemy's line of sight; if you can see a creature, you can discern whether it can see you.

On a successful check, you have the {@condition Invisible|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition. Make note of your check's total, which becomes the DC for a creature to find you with a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

The condition ends on you immediately after any of the following occurrences: you make a sound louder than a whisper, an enemy finds you, you make an attack roll, or you cast a spell with a verbal component.

action.name: Influence
entries: With the Influence action, you can try to influence another creature to do one thing that you request or demand.

The DM determines when this action is available, and it can be used only on creatures controlled by the DM. It isn't mind control; it can't force a creature to do something that is counter to the creature's alignment or that is otherwise repugnant to the creature.
This action has three main parts: Attitude, interaction, and a Charisma check.

entries.name: Attitude
entries: A creature's Attitude determines how a character can influence that creature. Each DMcontrolled creature has one of the following Attitudes toward player characters:

items.name: Indifferent
entries: This is the default Attitude for DMcontrolled creatures. An Indifferent creature might help or hinder the party, depending on what the creature sees as most beneficial. A creature's indifference doesn't necessarily make it standoffish or disinterested. Indifferent creatures might be polite and genial, surly and irritable, or anything in between. A successful Charisma check is usually necessary when the adventurers try to influence an Indifferent creature to do something.

items.name: Friendly
entries: A Friendly creature wants to help the adventurers and wishes for them to succeed. For tasks or actions that require no particular risk, effort, or cost, Friendly creatures often help happily, with the Charisma check succeeding automatically. If an element of personal risk is involved, a successful Charisma check is usually required to convince a Friendly creature to take that risk.

items.name: Hostile
entries: A Hostile creature opposes the adventurers and their goals but doesn't necessarily attack them on sight. The adventurers need to succeed on one or more Charisma checks to convince a Hostile creature to do anything on the party's behalf; however, the DM might determine that the Hostile creature is so ill-disposed toward the characters that no Charisma check can sway it. In which case, the first check fails automatically and no further Influence attempts can be made on the creature unless its Attitude shifts.

entries.name: Interaction
entries: When you take the Influence action, either roleplay how your character interacts with the creature or describe your character's behavior, focusing on your character's request or demand. If the interaction is especially suited to the creature's desires and outlook, the DM might temporarily shift a Hostile creature to Indifferent or an Indifferent creature to Friendly.
Similarly, if the interaction is particularly irksome to the creature, the DM might temporarily shift a Friendly creature to Indifferent or an Indifferent creature to Hostile.

entries.name: Charisma Check
entries: To determine whether your request or demand is successful, make a Charisma check. You have Advantage on the check if the creature is Friendly, and you have Disadvantage if the creature is Hostile.

entries.name: Choosing a Skill
entries: The Influence Skills table suggests which skills are applicable when you make the Charisma check, depending on the interaction that precedes the roll.

entries.caption: Influence Skills
rows: Gently coaxing a Beast or a Monstrosity
Deceiving a creature that can understand you
Persuading a creature that can understand you

entries.name: Setting the DC
entries: The DM sets the check's DC. A good guideline is to set the DC at 15 or at the creature's Intelligence or Wisdom score, whichever of those three numbers is highest.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: If your check succeeds, the creature does as you requested or demanded, based on its understanding and driven by its alignment; it won't do anything that it finds repugnant. If your check fails, you must wait to make the same request again. The default wait time is 24 hours, which the DM may shorten or extend depending on the circumstances.

action.name: Magic
entries: When you take the Magic action, you magic something by casting a spell that has a casting time of an action or by using a feature or Magic Item that requires a Magic action to be activated.

If you cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 minute or longer, you must take the Magic action on each turn of that casting, and you must maintain {@status Concentration} while you do so. If your {@status Concentration} is broken, the spell fails, but you don't expend a spell slot.

action.name: Search
entries: When you take the Search action, you make a Wisdom check to discern something that isn't obvious. The Search table suggests which skills are applicable when you take this action, depending on what you're trying to detect.

action.name: Study
entries: When you take the Study action, you make an Intelligence check to study your memory, a book, a creature, a clue, an object, or another source of knowledge and call to mind an important piece of information about it.
The Areas of Knowledge table suggests which skills are applicable when you take this action, depending on the area of knowledge the Intelligence check is about.

entries.caption: Areas of Knowledge
rows: Spells, magic items, eldritch symbols, magical traditions, planes of existence, and certain creatures (Aberrations, Constructs, Elementals, Fey, and Monstrosities)
Historic events and people, ancient civilizations, wars, and certain creatures (Giants and Humanoids)
Terrain, flora, weather, and certain creatures (Beasts, Dragons, Oozes, and Plants)
Deities, religious hierarchies and rites, holy symbols, cults, and certain creatures (Celestials, Fiends, and Undead)

sense.name: Blindsight
entries: If you have Blindsight, you can see within a specific range without relying on physical sight. Within that range, you can effectively see anything that isn't behind Total Cover, even if you have the {@condition Blinded} condition or are in Darkness. Moreover, in that range, you can effectively see a creature that has the {@condition Invisible|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition.

sense.name: Tremorsense
entries: A creature with Tremorsense can pinpoint the location of creatures and moving objects within a specific range, provided that the creature with Tremorsense and anything it's detecting are both in contact with the same surface (such as the ground, a wall, or a ceiling) or the same liquid.
Tremorsense can't detect creatures or objects in the air, and Tremorsense doesn't count as a form of sight.

sense.name: Truesight
entries: A creature with Truesight has enhanced vision within a specified range. Within that range, the creature's vision pierces through the following:

items.name: Darkness
entries: The creature can see in normal and magical darkness.

items.name: Invisibility
entries: The creature can see creatures that have the {@condition Invisible|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition and objects that are obscured by magic.

items.name: Visual Illusions
entries: Visual illusions appear transparent to the creature, and the creature automatically succeeds on saving throws against them.

items.name: Transformations
entries: The creature discerns the true form of any creature or object it sees that has been transformed by magic.

items.name: Ethereal Plane
entries: The creature can see into the Ethereal Plane.

data.name: Unearthed Arcana 2023 Player's Handbook Playtest 8
entries: This playtest document is part of a series of {@i Unearthed Arcana} articles that present material designed for the 2024 version of the {@i Player's Handbook}. The material here uses the rules in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, except where noted.

entries.name: Learn More on YouTube
entries: To learn more about the design in this article, we invite you to view the videos about it on YouTube ({@link www.youtube.com/DNDWizards}).

entries.name: What's Inside
entries: Here are the new and revised elements in this article:

items.name: Classes
entries: Three classes are here: {@class Barbarian|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, {@class Druid|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, and {@class Monk|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}. Each one includes one subclass: {@class Barbarian|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|Path of the World Tree (Barbarian)|World Tree|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, {@class Druid|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|Circle of the Moon (Druid)|Moon|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, and {@class Monk|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|Warrior of the Hand (Monk)|Hand|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}.

items.name: Spells
entries: New and revised spells are included.

items: The following sections were introduced in a previous article and are provided here for reference:

items.name: Weapons
entries: Weapon revisions are included.

items.name: Feats
entries: This includes a revised version of {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}.

items.name: Rules Glossary
entries: The rules glossary includes the few rules that have revised definitions in the playtest. In this document, any underlined term in the body text appears in the glossary.

entries.name: This Is Playtest Material
entries: This article is presented for playtesting and feedback. The options here are experimental and in draft form. They aren't officially part of the game. Your feedback will help determine whether we adopt it as official.

entries.name: How to Playtest This UA
entries: We invite you to try out this material in play. When you do so, you're welcome to combine this article with the other articles in this series, starting with "{@loader Character Origins.|collection/Unearthed Arcana 2022 - Character Origins.json|prerelease}"

If you do combine this article with any previous one, use only the rules glossary found here. In this {@i Unearthed Arcana} series, the rules glossary of each article supersedes the glossary of any previous article.

To play with this material, you may either incorporate it into your campaign or run one or more special playtest sessions. For such a session, you may create an adventure of your own or use a short adventure from a source like {@adventure Keys from the Golden Vault|KftGV}, {@adventure Journeys through the Radiant Citadel|JttRC}, or {@adventure Candlekeep Mysteries|CM}.

entries.name: Power Level
entries: The character options you read here might be more or less powerful than options in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}. If a design survives playtesting, we adjust its power to the desirable level before publication. This means an option could be more or less powerful in its final form.

entries.name: Feedback
entries: The best way for you to give us feedback on this material is in the survey we'll release on D&D Beyond. If we make this material official, it will be refined based on your feedback, and then it will appear in a D&D book.
Providing feedback on this document is one way you can help shape the next generation of D&D!

data.name: Classes
entries: {@note For full details of all classes including tables, multiclassing, equipment, core stats and fluff, please see {@filter the classes page|classes|source=XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}.}

entries.name: Design Note: Barbarian Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this class since its last playtest version:

items.name: Rage
entries: now regains one expended Rage when you finish a Short Rest.

items.name: Brutal Strike
entries: (formerly Brutal Critical) is a new feature that lets you trade the Advantage granted by your Reckless Attack for tactical options.

items.name: Improved Brutal Strike
entries: expands the options of your Brutal Strike feature at levels 13 and 17.

items.name: Persistent Rage
entries: now restores all uses of your Rage once per {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, and the {@condition Unconscious|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} condition, not {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, shuts off your Rage.

entries.name: Barbarian Subclasses
entries: A Barbarian subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain levels, as specified in the subclass. This section presents the {@class Barbarian|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|Path of the World Tree|World Tree|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} subclass.

entries.name: Design Note: Path of the World Tree Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since its last playtest version:

items.name: Vitality of the Tree
entries: now provides Temporary Hit Points to the Barbarian. In addition, the range to give Temporary Hit Points to a character increases to 20 feet at level 10.

items.name: Branches of the Tree
entries: now activates at the start of a creature's turn instead of the end. The range has increased to 30 feet, and the Barbarian can choose to reduce the Speed of a teleported creature to 0.

items.name: Battering Roots
entries: now applies its increased range only during your turn and only for weapons with specific properties. The feature now clarifies you can potentially use two Mastery properties in one attack.

items.name: Travel Along the Tree
entries: has been redesigned to allow you to teleport yourself while your Rage is active, as well as to teleport yourself and your allies a greater distance once per Rage.

entries.name: Design Note: Druid Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this class since its last playtest version:

items.name: Wild Shape
entries: now allows the Druid to know more Beast forms, and it gives Temporary Hit Points to the Druid. In addition, the Beast form no longer retains the Druid's species traits.

entries.name: Druid Subclasses
entries: A Druid subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Druid levels, as specified in the subclass.

Druids form loose associations, which they call circles, to facilitate their gatherings and preserve their traditions. This section presents the {@class Druid|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|Circle of the Moon subclass|Moon|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}.

entries.name: Design Note: Circle of the Moon Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since its last playtest version:

items.name: Circle Spells
entries: is a new feature that provides spells that you always have prepared and can cast in Wild Shape form.

items.name: Circle Forms
entries: (formerly Combat Wild Shape) has been streamlined to determine your AC and the number of Temporary Hit Points gained.

items.name: Improved Circle Forms
entries: allows you to make two Lunar Swipe attacks as an action, as well as add your Wisdom modifier to your Constitution saving throws while in a Wild Shape form.

items.name: Lunar Form
entries: now also improves Lunar Swipe.

entries.name: Design Note: Monk Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this class since its last playtest version:

items.name: Martial Arts
entries: sees the return of Monk Weapons, and the Martial Arts die applies to both {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|Unarmed Strikes} and Monk Weapons.

items.name: Bonus Unarmed Strike
entries: is no longer tied to the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} action.

items.name: Dexterous Attacks
entries: now allows you to use your Dexterity Modifier in place of your Strength modifier when setting the saving throw DC of the Grapple and Push options of your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|Unarmed Strikes}.

items.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: is cut.

items.name: Monk's Discipline
entries: (formerly Martial Discipline) options have been redesigned to have options that don't require spending Discipline Points.

items.name: Uncanny Metabolism
entries: (formerly Heightened Metabolism) moves to level 2, and now regains Discipline Points when you roll Initiative as well as regaining a number of Hit Points.

items.name: Deflect Attacks
entries: (formerly Deflect Missiles) now also works against melee attacks, and the damage of the Reaction now includes your Dexterity modifier.

items.name: Stunning Strike
entries: now deals Force damage if the creature succeeds on the saving throw.

items.name: Heightened Discipline
entries: is a new feature that increases the effects of Flurry of Blows, Patient Defense, and Step of the Wind.

items.name: Self-Restoration
entries: now allows you to remove some conditions at the end of your turns.

items.name: Deflect Energy
entries: now also works against melee attacks.

items.name: Superior Defense
entries: can now be activated at the start of your turn instead of using an action or a Bonus Action.

items.name: Perfect Discipline
entries: (formerly Perfect Self) now gives you expended Discipline Points if you have 3 or less.

items.name: Body and Mind
entries: is a new level 20 feature.

entries.name: Monk Subclasses
entries: A Monk subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain levels, as specified in the subclass. This section presents the {@class Monk|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8|Warrior of the Hand subclass|Hand|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}.

entries.name: Design Note: Warrior of the Hand Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since its last playtest version:

items.name: Open Hand Technique
entries: now has the Addle option to prevent creatures from making Opportunity Attacks and no longer requires a saving throw.

items.name: Wholeness of Body
entries: now allows you to regain Hit Points without expending Discipline Points.

items.name: Fleet Step
entries: now allows you to take the Step of the Wind option alongside other Bonus Actions.

items.name: Quivering Palm
entries: now allows you the option to replace one of your attacks with the action to end the vibrations on the creature. To compensate for this increased flexibility, the cost and damage of the feature has been adjusted.

data.name: Spells
entries: This section presents new or revised spells for you to playtest.

entries.name: Class Tags
entries: A spell's description contains one or more tags indicating the class spell lists that contain the spell. For example, if a spell has the "Wizard" tag, the spell is on the Wizard spell list.

entries.name: Spell Descriptions
entries: The following spells are presented in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Design Note: Spell Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this section since its last playtest version:

items.name: Conjure Animals, Conjure Celestial, Conjure Elemental, Conjure Fey, Conjure Minor Elementals,
entries: and {@b Conjure Woodland Beings} have all been redesigned to differentiate them from the summoning spells from {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE}, which will appear in the 2024 {@i Player's Handbook}.

items.name: Cure Wounds
entries: healing has increased to {@dice 2d8}, and the healing improves by {@dice 2d8} at higher levels.

items.name: Fount of Moonlight
entries: is a new level 4 spell for Bards and Druids.

items.name: Healing Word
entries: healing has increased to {@dice 2d4}, and the healing improves by {@dice 2d4} at higher levels.

items.name: Mass Cure Wounds
entries: now heals for {@dice 5d8} instead of {@dice 3d8}.

items.name: Mass Healing Word
entries: now heals for {@dice 2d4} instead of {@dice 1d4}.

items.name: Power Word Fortify
entries: is a new spell for Bards and Clerics.

items.name: Starry Wisp
entries: is a new cantrip for Bards and Druids.

entries.name: Parts of a Feat
entries: The description of a feat contains the following parts, which are presented after the feat's name:

items.name: Category
entries: A feat is a member of a category, which is noted in the feat. If you are instructed to choose a feat from a specific category, such as the Background category, that category must appear under the feat's name.

items.name: Prerequisite
entries: You must meet any prerequisite specified in a feat to take that feat unless a special feature allows you to take the feat without the prerequisite. If a prerequisite is a level, your character level must meet or exceed that level. If a prerequisite is a class, you must have at least one level in that class to qualify for the feat.

items.name: Benefit
entries: The benefit of the feat is then detailed. If you have a feat, you gain its benefit.

items.name: Repeatable
entries: A feat can be taken only once unless it states otherwise.

entries.name: Feat Descriptions
entries: Here are descriptions of some feats that are available to characters using this playtest article. Playtest characters can also select feats from previous installments of the 2022 {@i Unearthed Arcana} series.
If a feat appears in this article and also in one of those earlier articles, use the version of the feat in this article.

data.name: Weapons
entries: This section contains playtest versions of weapons in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}. Here you'll find weapon tables, revised weapon properties, and a new type of property: Mastery properties.

entries.name: Weapon Properties
entries: Here are properties whose definitions have changed for this playtest.

entries.name: Heavy
entries: A Heavy weapon is unwieldy compared to other weapons. You have Disadvantage on your attack rolls with a Heavy weapon if it's a melee weapon and your Strength score isn't at least 13 and if it's a ranged weapon and your Dexterity score isn't at least 13.

entries.name: Light
entries: When you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} action on your turn and attack with a Light weapon, you can make one extra attack as a Bonus Action later on the same turn. That extra attack must be made with a different Light weapon, and you don't add your ability modifier to the extra attack's damage, unless that modifier is negative.

For example, if you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8} action on your turn and have a Shortsword in one hand and a Dagger in the other—each of which has the Light property—you can make one attack with each weapon, using your action and a Bonus Action, but you don't add your Strength or Dexterity modifier to the damage roll of the Bonus Action, unless that modifier is negative.

entries.name: Thrown
entries: If a weapon has the Thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack, and you can draw that weapon as part of the attack.

If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a Handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a Dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the Dagger has the Finesse property.

entries.name: Mastery Properties
entries: Each weapon now has a Mastery property, as shown in the weapon tables above. That property is usable only by a character who has a feature, such as Weapon Mastery, that unlocks the property for the character.
Here are descriptions of each Mastery property. The properties are provided in alphabetical order.
If a game feature lets you replace a weapon's Mastery property with another one, that weapon must meet any prerequisite specified for the new property.

data.name: Adventuring Gear
entries: Here are descriptions of miscellaneous items whose rules have changed for this playtest.

data.name: Rules Glossary
entries: This glossary includes game terms that have new meaning in this playtest document, as well as terms, such as {@variantrule creature type|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP8}, that aren't defined in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}. The terms are organized alphabetically.

If a term doesn't appear here, use its definition in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, and when playtesting this document, don't use the rules glossary of any other {@i Unearthed Arcana} article.
